I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan, 
and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Urban Transport Electrification Project. 
The report also describes the proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the High-Level 
Technology Fund for the Urban Transport Electrification Project, and if the Board approves the 
proposed loan and grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the 
administration of the grant. 
 
2.  The proposed project will jumpstart a long-term transition towards a zero tailpipe-emission 
transport sector in the Kyrgyz Republic. It will comprise four interlinked outputs: (i) zero-emission 
tailpipe bus fleet in Bishkek municipality upgraded, (ii) bus depot infrastructure upgraded, (iii) pilot 
green mobility corridor established, and (iv) Bishkek bus operation sustainability improved. The 
project is economically justified by the reduced need for fossil fuel imports, vehicle operating cost 
savings, better air quality, and reduced carbon emissions, which will promote energy security, 
improve public health, and contribute to climate change mitigation. The project will also make 
Bishkek more livable and foster gender equity. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Background and Issues. The Kyrgyz Republic is rich in renewable energy resources. It 
produces more than 91% of its electricity from hydropower and, despite its vast hydropower 
capacity of 3,068 megawatts, untapped technical potential is estimated to be more than 10 times 
this amount.1 Despite its wealth in hydro resources, the Kyrgyz Republic is heavily dependent on 
the import of fossil fuels in the residential, transport, and industrial sector, with about 90% of the 
country’s domestic demand for gasoline, diesel, and compressed natural gas (CNG) being 
imported. In 2019, the Kyrgyz Republic spent more than $900 million or 11.1% of its national 
gross domestic product on the import of fossil fuels, exposing the country to significant price 
fluctuations in the international oil and gas markets. 
 
4.  Bishkek, the capital and economic center of the Kyrgyz Republic, accounts for 40% of the 
country’s gross domestic product, and is home to one-sixth of the Kyrgyz Republic’s population. 
Since 2000, the city has experienced an average annual population growth rate of 1.5%, reaching 
1.02 million inhabitants in 2019. This growth has brought a rapid increase in motorization, fuel 
consumption, and traffic congestion resulting in combustion emissions of local air pollutants and 
greenhouse gases (GHGs).  
 
5.  Since 2005, passenger car density in Bishkek has quintupled, with 480,000 of the 1.2 million 
registered vehicles nationwide located in the capital region.2 From 2011 to 2016, the national 
consumption  of  petroleum  products  and  CNG  increased  by  27.8%,  underlining  the  growing 
economic burden and fuel import dependency caused by the country’s resource-intensive transport 
sector.3 As most vehicles are more than 20 years old and run on low-quality fuel without regular 
technical inspections, the increase in urban motor vehicles has led to a significant deterioration in 
air quality. In 2018, during the nonheating season, the average concentration of major air pollutants 
such as nitrogen dioxide (NO ) and fine particulate matter of less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter 
2

2

for PM2.5—far exceeding the air quality guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO).4 In 
December 2020, air quality in Bishkek was rated as very unhealthy, with recorded PM levels of 
2.5 
184 µg/m³; a value more than 18 times above the WHO recommended air quality threshold.  
 
6.  The transport sector is responsible for 75% of air pollution in Bishkek (footnote 3), and 
WHO estimates that outdoor air pollution causes about 400 premature deaths annually.5 As buses 
cause about half of transport-related PM  and NO  emissions in Bishkek, the public transport 
2.5 2
segment has been identified as a major contributor to air pollution.6 
 
7.  A major reason for the high emission contribution of public transport is the large number 
of outdated minibuses, which dominate public transport in the capital.7 Following the collapse of 
the Soviet Union, chronic underfunding has led to the downsizing of the city’s municipality-owned 
large bus fleet—resulting in the rapid emergence of private sector minibus operators.8 Since 1989, 
the number of municipality-operated large buses has declined from 617 to 313 units. In contrast, 
minibuses operating in the city have increased from 450 to more than 4,071 vehicles during the 
same period, aggressively taking over routes from public service providers.9 Compared with 1989, 
minibus operators have expanded their services from 20 routes to 106 routes, while the route 
system covered by the two municipality-owned companies has decreased from 66 routes to 
25 routes (footnote 9). Despite passengers’ preference for the safer, more comfortable, and 
lower-cost large public buses, the lack of vehicles, reduced service frequency, and limited routes 
have forced passengers onto the expanding fleet of minibuses. 
 
8.  On national level, the Kyrgyz Republic’s transport sector accounts for 28% of national 
GHG emissions. As the country has a very low grid emission factor (0.13 kilograms of carbon 
dioxide [CO ] per kilowatt-hour), electrification of the sector could contribute significantly to the 
2
country’s climate target of reducing GHG emissions by 11.5%–13.8% by 2030 compared with 
business as usual (footnote 3). The project will contribute to help the Kyrgyz Republic meet its 
national determined contributions under the Paris Climate Agreement.  
 
9.  Government Strategy. The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic intends to capitalize its 
hydro-dominated clean energy sector to help address the highly polluting urban transport sector 
in Bishkek, with the objective to decrease the transport sector’s GHG, PM2.5 and NO2 emissions. 
To reach this aim, the government has declared the transition to environment-friendly modes of 
transport as one of its top policy priorities in its National Development Strategy, 2018–2040.10 To 
stimulate the adoption of electric vehicles, numerous tax and duty exemptions on electric vehicles 
and related charging infrastructure have been proposed and implemented. In addition, the 
government introduced a preferential electricity tariff for public electric vehicle charging in March 
2020. 
 
10.  Alignment  with  ADB  Strategy  2030.  The  project  is  designed  with  cross-sectoral 
collaboration in the energy-urban transport nexus and is closely aligned with ADB’s Strategy

3 
2030. The project will focus on four out of seven operational priorities by (i) tackling climate 
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability; (ii) 
making cities more livable; (iii) accelerating progress in gender equality; and (iv) strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity.11 
 
11.  ADB and Development Partner Engagement. ADB to date has been assisting with 
improvement of the reliability of existing infrastructure as well as the rehabilitation of major 
hydropower plants, and national transmission and distribution network. In the urban transport 
sector, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has supported the 
Bishkek  Municipal  Government  by  procuring  a  total  of  131  large  trolleybuses.  The  limited 
interventions of EBRD since 2011 have not been able to stop the trend of an increasingly 
dominant role of privately-operated minibuses in Bishkek’s public transport sector.  
 
12.  Lessons learned. The project design incorporates lessons from past assistance, notably 
the need for (i) strong political support and consensus, (ii) thorough project preparation to achieve 
readiness before project approval, (iii) trainings on new technology involved in battery electric 
buses (BEBs) and charging infrastructure, as well as (iv) the provision of capacity building and 
consistent monitoring to ensure compliance with the safeguard requirements of ADB.12 
 
13.  Private Sector Engagement. Private sector opportunities are being sought on the project 
to enhance the financial sustainability of the bus system. In particular, private sector contracts are 
being pursued for: (i) advertising both at the bus shelters as well as inside and outside the 
vehicles; and (ii) commercial kiosk rental at the bus shelters. In addition, the project will be 
investigating the potential to commercialize the placement of mobile or broadband antennae on 
system infrastructure, including shelters and the new street lighting. The potential privatization of 
an on-street parking management system is another area being investigated for system revenue 
generation. 
 
14.  In phase 1 of the project, the electric bus operations will be delivered by the state-owned 
trolleybus company, the Bishkek Trolleybus Department (BTD). This arrangement will ensure 
operational integration and continuity. However, ADB is already engaging with the government 
on a phase 2 project in which electric vehicle development will be widened to private sector actors, 
including potentially both private taxi operators and private marshrutka (van service) operators.  
Thus, as the project proceeds, opportunities for private sector participation will likely increase, 
along with the introduction of gross-based contracting and other business model innovations. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
15.  The project is aligned with the following impact: transition to environment-friendly modes 
of transport promoted (footnote 10). The project will have the following outcome: environmental, 
health, and economic impacts of Bishkek’s public transport sector reduced.13 
 
16.  Output  1:  Zero-emission  tailpipe  bus  fleet  in  Bishkek  municipality  upgraded. 
Output 1 will encompass the procurement of (i) 120 modern BEBs; (ii) 35 100kW and 35 300 kW 
chargers, including cabling, electrical and civil works; and (iii) substation infrastructure. All BEBs

will include universal accessibility design features to serve the needs of disabled and elderly 
passengers as well as women with children. In addition, BEBs will be equipped with security 
features, such as cameras and panic buttons, to cater to the needs of female and vulnerable 
passengers. 
 
17.  Output 2: Bus depot infrastructure upgraded. In at least one existing trolleybus depot 
additional weather-protected parking facilities, and rain shields for charging infrastructure will be 
established to accommodate the fleet of 120 BEBs. In addition, pavement improvements will be 
implemented. 
 
18.  Output 3: Pilot green mobility corridor established. A BEB pilot corridor will be 
established to reduce congestion in the city center, demonstrate improved traffic and parking 
management, and increase bus speed and service reliability. This output consists of (i) the 
provision of a dedicated busway lane which will increase average commercial bus speeds from 
15 km per hour to 20 km per hour; (ii) improvements to at least three traffic junctions, including 
improvements to signalization synchronization, signage and road markings, and safe pedestrian 
crossings; and (iii) introduction of a new parking policy along the length of the corridor. The parking 
policy will address (i) the physical formalization of parking infrastructure, especially along the 
demonstration corridor; (ii) management and revenue collection of on-street parking; and, (iii) 
potential application of a parking levy on off-street, non-residential parking as a future revenue 
source for the overall public transport system. The parking policy is key to the overall project for 
two reasons: (i) existing uncontrolled parking conditions will interfere with the safe and reliable 
operation of the dedicated bus services on the demonstration corridor; and (ii) parking represents 
a potential revenue source that can be hypothecated to the public transport system to ensure 
ongoing financial sustainability. 
 
19.  Output 4: Bishkek bus operation sustainability improved. Output 4 will support the 
municipality in improving its management of urban mobility and the efficiency and financial 
sustainability of public transport operations through (i) the reduction of operational expenditures 
per vehicle-km travelled by 10%; (ii) an enhanced institutional framework and urban mobility 
management system; (iii) development of a transport demand model to allow better route and 
operational decision making; (iv) professionalization of the business model including revenues 
from private sector opportunities in advertising, commercial sales, and parking management; (v) 
delivery of capacity-development training sessions on electric bus operation and maintenance, 
infrastructure maintenance, and business opportunity development, with at least 20% of the 
training participants being women; (vi) knowledge and skill development of bus drivers and 
conductors to handle incidents of violence against women and other vulnerable groups; and (vii) 
an employment priority program to ensure at least 20% of the bus drivers are women.    
 
20.  The proposed modernization of Bishkek’s large bus fleet, with state-of-the-art large BEBs, 
is a move to address the chronic issues of public buses to enable a shift away from the unsafe, 
overcrowded, and highly polluting minibuses. 
 
21.  By replacing 95 diesel and 25 outdated trolleybuses with BEBs, the project will result in 
an annual net energy import savings of $1,080,000 and economic benefits of $538,000 million 
(including $86,000 in health benefits). Following the successful deployment of the initial batch of 
BEBs, the project foresees a modular scale-up of up to 130 additional BEBs. In this initial 
procurement, though, no minibuses or vans will be replaced, and thus no livelihood impacts for 
the  industry  are  expected.  The  project  will  initiate  progressive  electrification  of the  Kyrgyz 
Republic’s transport sector and, because of its distinctive long-term economic, environmental, 
and urban transport-related benefits, will have a lasting positive impact on the country.

5 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
22.  Building on ADB’s earlier engagement in the energy sector, which particularly focused on 
the expansion of renewable power generation and improvement of the national grid system 
reliability, this project will add benefit by enabling the public transport sector to utilize domestically 
produced clean electricity in the hitherto fossil-fuel dominated public transport fleet. Moreover, the 
project  will  provide  institutional  reform  recommendations  to  improve  the  efficiency  and 
coordination of the fragmented Bishkek public transport system. ADB will ensure best practices 
in project design and implementation by mobilizing leading international experts in BEB systems 
and by building up a skilled labor force for the O&M of BEB vehicle fleets. The project is aligned 
with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic, 2018–2022 and the country 
operations business plan for the Kyrgyz Republic, 2021–2023 as well as ADB’s sustainable 
transport initiative.14 
 
23.  The project will demonstrate that the implementation of a state-of-the-art BEB fleet, in 
combination with the planned pilot corridor, is a viable option to (i) promote energy security, while 
reducing the economic burden incurred by fuel imports; (ii) reduce air pollutants and GHG 
emissions of Bishkek’s public transport system; (iii) improve public health; (iv) reduce congestion 
in the city center; and (v) improve the ridership of environment-friendly large buses. 
 
24.  The project will promote gender equality and include the following gender elements: (i) 
designated seats for women, children, the elderly, and persons with disabilities; (ii) sufficient 
space for baby strollers and wheelchairs; (iii) security features, such as panic buttons; (iv) onboard 
CCTV cameras; (v) an information campaign against violence and the harassment of women; and 
(vi) training of bus drivers on conduct in cases of violence, sexual harassment, and crimes against 
women. To promote gender equality at the company level, the BTD has committed to ensure that 
at least 20% of BEB bus drivers and 40% of technicians are female. 
 
25.  Despite the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, supply chains for BEBs and 
chargers are robust. Passenger demand in Bishkek for trolleybus and bus services fell by 47% 
(reduction of 28.9 million passenger trips) from 2019 to 2020 due to the ongoing pandemic. The 
provision of the new BEB fleet and the dedicated busway corridor will assist in recovering this 
demand in the post-pandemic period through more frequent services and time savings. Given 
both the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the likely specter of future pandemics, the project’s 
beneficial air quality impact will contribute to decreased incidence of respiratory diseases, thus, 
indirectly relieving the public health system, as air pollution is a recognized aggravator of 
respiratory illness.15 Moreover, the utilization of spacious BEBs will provide a more secure travel 
option for passengers than crowded minibus services.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
30.  The borrower is the Ministry of Economy and Finance, which will enter into a subsidiary loan 
and grant agreement with the Bishkek Mayor’s Office (BMO). The BMO, which will act as the 
project’s executing agency, will provide the proceeds of the loans and grants as grants to the two 
implementing agencies: the BTD and the Urban Transport Department (UTD). The BTD will be 
responsible for the implementation of outputs 1 and 2, while the UTD will be in charge of outputs 3 
and 4. The Department of Transport and Municipal Property under the BMO will serve as the project 
management unit (PMU). The PMU’s responsibilities include overseeing the project implementation 
activities  of  the  two  implementing  agencies,  procurement,  contract,  and  overall  project 
administration, as well as safeguard compliance and reporting. The PMU will further act as 
secretariat for the project steering committee. The implementation arrangements are summarized 
in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM (footnote 16).

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
32.  A detailed comparative analysis of different technologies was conducted, evaluating the 
technical, environmental, and economic performance of diesel, CNG, conventional and hybrid 
trolleybuses, and slow- and fast-charging BEBs. The analysis was made based on the climatic, 
route, and operational conditions of public transport operators in Bishkek; and it identified fast-
charging BEBs as the most suitable technology option. 
 
33.  Since hydropower produces more than 91% of electricity in the Kyrgyz Republic, the 
project will have significant positive energy security, air quality, and climate benefits. Depending 
on the time of the year, BEBs can be run up to 100% by renewable electricity. In comparison with 
diesel and CNG buses, which are major sources of PM and NOx, BEBs (i) have zero combustion 
2.5 
emissions of these pollutants; (ii) have up to 40% lower operation and maintenance (O&M) costs; 
(iii) have a longer lifetime; and (iv) with a high renewable energy share in the power mix, facilitate a 
long-term decarbonization of the transport sector.18 From a GHG perspective, BEBs exhibit the 
lowest well-to-wheel CO  emissions of all evaluated technologies.19 On an annual basis, the 
2
project will mitigate 10,800 tons of CO  equivalent and will contribute to improved air quality by 
2
reducing the emission of 2 tons of PM and 98 tons of NOx per year.20 
2.5 
 
34.  The project supports technological innovation in the Kyrgyz Republic and will improve the 
efficiency and stability of the power system and the safety of the public transport system. The 
state-of-the-art battery technology and its fast-charging capability will allow for a maximum degree 
of operational flexibility. BEBs can be recharged from 20% to 80% of battery state of charge in 
less than 30 minutes. Compared with the trolleybus system, BEBs (i) are 60% more energy-
efficient; (ii) are beneficial to the power system during electricity shortages, as BEBs are only 
recharged during off-peak hours; (iii)  can operate independent from the existing trolleybus 
catenary system; (iv) are less affected by localized blackouts; and (v) assuming a full transition to 
a 100% BEB system, will make costly investments of an estimated $31 million into the dilapidated 
catenary system and supporting substations redundant.21 
 
35.  Fast-charged BEB systems are a proven technology that have been used worldwide in 
cities with similar climatic conditions, such as Beijing (11,000 units) and Harbin (600 units) in the 
People’s Republic of China, and Helsinki in Finland (51 units). BEBs and charging infrastructure 
specifications have been adapted for cold winter conditions in Bishkek. The implementing agency, 
BTD, has extensive experience in the O&M of trolleybus systems, facilitating the transition toward

B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
36.  The project’s economic and financial viability was assessed following ADB guidelines.22 
Fast-charging BEBs have the lowest total costs of ownership (TCO) in the context of Bishkek’s 
bus operations (footnote 6). The higher initial capital expenditure of BEBs is recovered because 
of their significantly lower energy and maintenance costs as well as the longer useful life of BEBs 
compared with fossil-fuel buses. The cost–benefit analysis was based on a comparison of an 
investment in BEBs with a baseline of 95 diesel and 25 conventional trolleybuses. The economic 
analysis includes (i) the procurement of the BEB fleet, (ii) charging infrastructure including grid 
upgrades, (iii) bus depot upgrades, (iv) the e-bus pilot corridor, and (v) related consulting services. 
 
37.  The project is economically viable and, with an estimated economic internal rate of return 
of 10.4%, is above the benchmark of 9.0%. The direct economic benefits of electric buses are 
reduced  expenditures  on  energy  and  maintenance  totaling  $1.82  million  per  year.  Indirect 
monetized benefits worth an annual average of $664,000 include (i) reduced air pollution (PM , 
2.5
SO , and NOx, based on local health cost estimates); (ii) reduced GHG emissions (based on the 
2
social cost of carbon); and (iii) decreased noise. The economic benefits of the pilot green mobility 
corridor are based on time savings and are estimated at $493,000 annually. A sensitivity analysis 
over  a range  of  parameters  and  price  change  fluctuations  demonstrates  that  the  project’s 
economic viability is robust. The project’s economic internal rate of return remains above the 
benchmark, with a 13% increase in e-bus investment, a 41% increase in capital expenditure of 
charging infrastructure including grid connection, a 192% increase in capital expenditure of bus 
depot upgrades, a 117% increase in electricity usage or prices, a 31% decline in economic 
benefits, and a 41% decline in time savings. 
 
38.  The financial analysis, assuming adequate subsidy funding from the government to bridge 
a deficit in the tariff for full cost recovery, confirmed the project’s financial viability, yielding an entity-
level financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for BTD of 3.9% and a project-level FIRR of 5.2%, which 
compare favorably with the estimated 3.3% weighted average cost of capital (WACC). To ensure a 
robust result, a separate sensitivity analysis was conducted, increasing by 5% and 10% the 
following: (i) WACC, (ii) capital expenditure, (iii) energy cost, and (iv) labor cost. The analysis 
concluded that the entity-level FIRR for BTD is generally more susceptible to increases in capital 
expenditure and labor costs, and heavily dependent on the government’s subsidies in adequate 
cash funding and electricity tariff support. In the case of no-subsidy scenario, the BTD’s FIRR of 
2.2% is potentially below WACC—meaning, without subsidies the project is not financially viable. 
To safeguard the project’s financial viability, relevant covenants have been included under the 
loan agreement of the project, committing the government to maintain the current level of 
subsidies. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
39.  Bishkek’s public bus segment is highly fragmented, consisting of the two municipality-
owned public transport companies and a multitude of private van and minibus operators, which 
are poorly coordinated. Public transport services are currently regulated by the UTD, which

oversees  route  licensing  and  system  quality.  Project  consultants  will  support  the  capacity 
development of UTD through training and other knowledge management activities. In addition, 
the project consultants will evaluate the institutional alternatives for the future, including the 
potential introduction of a transport authority, which would have broader planning and system 
management oversight. Only existing bus services are being upgraded with the new BEB 
vehicles. The existing van and minibus operators are unaffected by this initial procurement of 
BEBs (i.e., no route permits are removed for the van and minibus operators and thus no livelihood 
issues or crowding out of the private sector are expected). Compared with the other technologies, 
BEBs have (i) the lowest TCO per km, (ii) no tailpipe emissions (PM  and NOx), and (iii) very 
2.5
low  levels  of  GHG  emissions.  Supported  by  various  government  incentive  schemes  and 
subsidies, BEBs are not only ecologically but also financially and economically sustainable; and, 
with adequate institutional capacity improvements and reforms, BEBs will make bus operators 
less dependent on government subsidies in the long term. The project includes a 3-year O&M 
program,  with  capacity  building  to  reinforce  and  maintain  the  capacity  of  public  transport 
operators. Recurrent cost analysis has shown that, during project implementation, O&M costs are 
expected to decrease gradually, progressively reducing the reliance on government subsidies. 
Moreover, a budget analysis of the BMO has shown that historical and projected transportation 
costs were budgeted in excess of actual O&M costs, leaving sufficient fiscal headroom. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
40.  Financial  management.  The  assessed  pre-mitigation  financial  management  risk  is 
substantial mainly because of (i) weak internal and external audit arrangements in the internal 
control framework; (ii) the relatively weak financial management capacity of the executing and 
implementing agencies; (iii) the limited strength of finance and internal audit in the BMO, BTD, 
and UTD; (iv) the lack of experience of the executing and implementing agencies with ADB 
projects; and (v) the required migration of project financial reports from Microsoft Excel to the 1C 
accounting information system.23 The executing and implementing agencies agreed with ADB on 
a timebound financial management action plan and incorporated mitigation measures into the 
project design. 
 
41.  Procurement  and  anticorruption.  The  project  procurement  risk  subject  to  the 
procurement capacity of the BTD and the UTD was assessed following ADB’s guidelines. The 
procurement risk of the project is assessed high before mitigation measures, mainly because the 
implementing agencies have limited experience related to foreign-assisted projects and ADB 
procurement requirements.24 ADB will conduct regular training and capacity-building activities 
during processing and implementation, provide expert support to both implementing agencies, 
and monitor procurement activities. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the government, the BMO, the BTD, and the UTD. The specific 
policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 16). 
Integrity due diligence was also conducted.25 The executing agency, the BMO, is part of the 
government, and the implementing agency, the UTD (established in 2008), is a unit of the BMO; 
hence, both are exempt from integrity due diligence. No significant integrity risks were identified 
for the BTD.

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
42.  Most of Bishkek’s public transport trips are via vans and minibuses. Minibuses have a 
maximum capacity of 18 passengers and charge fares that are 25%–40% higher than municipality-
owned bus companies.26 Overcrowded minibuses do not provide sufficient safe seating space and 
expose women, the elderly, and children to the dangers of harassment and accidents. Further, it is 
estimated that 93% of wheelchair users never use public transport because of access difficulties.27 
The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. Key gender design features of the 
project that promote safe travel of women and other vulnerable groups are indicated in the gender 
action plan.28 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
43.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.29 
 
44.  Environment (category B). An initial environmental examination (IEE), including an 
environmental management plan (EMP), covering outputs 1 and 2, has been prepared following 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement based on the preliminary design. The IEE shows that any 
impacts  caused  by  construction  and  operation  will  be  site-specific,  short  in  duration,  not 
significant, and can be avoided and/or mitigated through measures identified in the EMP.30 The 
IEE will be updated based on detailed design and site-specific conditions. An environmental 
assessment and review framework (EARF) was prepared and agreed with ADB to (i) guide the 
selection,  screening  and  categorization,  environmental  assessment,  preparation,  and 
implementation of the safeguard plan of the pilot green mobility corridor (output 3), which will be 
prepared after Board approval; and (ii) facilitate compliance with the requirements specified in 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.31 The executing agency will engage qualified safeguard 
experts to monitor the construction works and ensure the implementation of the EMP. Contractors 
will be required to submit, as part of their bids, the expected costs for the implementation of the 
EMP and site-specific EMP to the executing agency before works start. Environmental reporting 
to ADB will be done on a semiannual basis and will continue until ADB issues the project 
completion report. All IEEs, the EARF, the EMPs, and corrective action plans (if any) will be 
disclosed on the websites of ADB, and the executing and implementing agencies. Consultation 
and  public  participation  will  continue  throughout  implementation,  and  any  environmental 
grievances will be handled in accordance with the grievance redress mechanism developed for 
the project.
